column5:
freyac, perhaps you should check your facts also.
tourism contributes between 15 and 20% of the gdp, that includes ancillary services, such as shopping, supply chains, etc. direct contributions are closer to 10 to 12% as jay mentioned. and while international arrivals have dwindled to record lows, domestic tourism is still contributing a small portion to assist the industry.
but the thai economy is not on its knees nor anywhere near being on its knees. nor are people starving. with the exception of those directly working in tourism (hotel staff, tour bus drivers, tour guides, entertainment, tourist restaurants) most people still have their former employment. those in tourism that were let go, have in large part left the tourist destinations and returned to their villages where they have family. thais don't let their fellow thais starve.
when the initial shutdowns happened, food pantries showed up all over the place, there were even some in our neighborhood. but over time as folks who were displaced found new work, the amount of food needed dropped off. now food donated takes quite a while before the supply is depleted.

column5:
i guess it depends on your taste for the finer things and spending on 'nightlife'. for a backpacker, $5k (~$330/day) would be a boatload of money. eating street food or casual restaurants and a few beers would cost you about $30-40 at most. transportation and visiting the sights maybe $20-100 depending. leaving you a couple hundred per day which you could spend on nightlife but even that would be extravagant. unless you have super expensive tastes and spend like a drunken sailor on the nightlife, your budget should be more than enough.
i can't speak to how well you'd be accepted as a black male, though the thais are generally very accepting of foreigners. i'd heard that there's been (pre-covid) a criminal element from africa that's makes people wary of black people in general but you'll need to dig deeper on this. as a solo traveler in thailand i found it easy to meet other travelers. it may depend on where you stay, though.
in terms of places to visit, don't miss the fantastic thai temples in bangkok. the temple of the emerald buddha/national palace, wat po, wat arun are some of the most popular. a tour of the klongs in a long tail boat is a must see, imho. if you can, try to make a day trip to ayuthaya for the ruined temples. the floating market is great but couple it with a tour of the surrounding canals.
i haven't been to pattaya in decades but my impression is that it's mostly about the nightlife with little else to do. it's not a great beach destination. imo. others may correct me on this. if you're not married to spending 8 days in pattaya consider splitting the time with koh samui or krabi or phuket. much better beach destinations and still nightlife around.
good luck with your trip!

column5:
i’ve stayed in both twice and there are fine margins between them.
we’ve had a gold deluxe corner suite at the fairmont as well as a gold deluxe standard room - i like the location of the fairmont especially as the last few years has seen a lot more about within close proximity. it’s easier to reach the mainland.
the lounge and bar area ( think it’s called honor bar) isn’t huge and i’d say not as plentiful if you’re comparing to other 5* hotels in dubai. it does a decent afternoon selection of snacks, cakes etc and somewhere to escape for an hour or so in the afternoon.
be mindful if you’re travelling with kids as i don’t believe kids are allowed in once evening drinks are served however we noticed on both visitors kids were in post 6pm. as we had our young daughter with us we only went in the lounge a few evenings when our little one was at her grandparents so i was quite surprised to see kids in there as i don’t think they’re officially allowed as when we stayed there wasn’t a separate family section but this might have changed.
having a gold room gave us complimentary access for 2 hrs to the kids club otherwise it was chargeable at dhs 50 per session however it was 2015 & 2018 when i stayed so it might have changed. again though if you’re not travelling with kids then it’s irrelevant to you.
one of my favourite restaurants, little miss india, is at the fairmont and well worth a visit.
the standard gold rooms are okay but not wow factor but the hotel itself is lovely. it’s downside for me is the pools are quite busy, it has a separate adults pool but is generally busy with day guests and the family pool direct doesn’t have a large amount of beds and most are on the sand.....
it has a great kids pool for wee ones and it’s kids club is very good complete with climbing wall and splash fountains.
probably not an issue for most but my hubby thought the lager choice around the pool was limited. i still recall him whinging at paying over 50dhs for a pint of lukewarm heineken lol...
anantara - the obvious drawback is it’s further out being on the far end of the crescent. i like the setting of the anantara and the fact it has quite a unique style. i think the buffet restaurant is better than the buffet at the fairmont, it has a few a la carte and the far eastern was my favourite but i also liked the beach house restaurant and outdoor bar area.
both times we stayed we had a lagoon room but in one stay we were upgraded to a villa half way through due to an electrical issue in our room!
for me the swim up rooms are a real bonus, it’s great just being able to go straight into the pool, it also means the main pool doesn’t get too crowded!
there’s a small kids club and staff are lovely and there’s a few pool kids activities going on through the day. the kids club at the fairmont is better.
another bonus of the swim up rooms is you can purchase duty free and drink them freely on your balcony ( there’s two loungers on each lagoon access balcony ) as well as snacks thus saving money, there is also a little boat that comes around selling drinks and i purchased a few afternoon mojitos!!
between the two, i prefer the anantara, only fine margins but the lagoon access rooms are the main bonus.
to sum up both really good but i’d pick a lagoon access room over a standard gold room. just a tip, we stayed in a lagoon access room which was the furthest room in our block right next to the bridge to access the spa. this was a great room as it got afternoon sun but due to it being furthest away was quite private and we had some inflatable lilos which we just sunbathed on in the lagoon and never saw a soul. the lagoons are busier in the middle.
one slight drawback to the anantara is it can be quiet in the evening, suited us fine but if you prefer a slightly
busier vibe then fairmont might suit you better.

column5:
hi there
we spent a month in thailand feb 2020 with our children aged 8 and 11. absolutely amazing experience and so worthwhile doing with them.
our itinerary was:
3 nights bangkok stayed at ibis riverside (great family rooms)
2 nights khao yai stayed at greenleaf and did the afternoon tour on 1st day then full day tour on 2nd day. absolutely amazing place and greenleaf is highly recommended. tours were incredible and we saw wild elephants as well as so much else.
next we got train to ayutthaya and spent afternoon on temple tour before getting night train to chiang mai.
7 nights at chiang mai which again absolutely fabulous with kids. highlights were day with karen tribe native elephants (cant recommended highly enough), sticky waterfalls, big game fishing, grand canyon water park.
then we got direct flight to krabi and taxi to koh lanta for 5 nights. koh lanta amazing and very family friendly. best day ever was a private long-tail trip to koh rok, most magical day of my life with lanta paradise i think was called. also loved car hire and going to national park, and mangrove kayaking trip.
after this we got speedboat to koh mook for 3 nights. very quiet but very pretty and a totally different vibe as not at all developed, no real roads, no 7/11, no atm etc. loved it here, only thing put me off going back was a hotel behind main beach been knocked down and was quite a building site.
next got speedboat to koh lipe for 4 nights. stayed at castaway in family house. absolutely stunning here, like nowhere else i've been. but busier. snorkeling incredible and the water the most beautiful crystal clear turquoise colour. loved it.
then flew from hat yai to bangkok for 1 more night before heading home.
i would love to do it again and would not hesitate to encourage others to travel to thailand with young families. enjoy the planning i'm very envious!!!

column5:
vietnam is one of the easiest places to get around on your own, it is a well trod backpackers hang out. there are bus routes from anywhere to everywhere. we spent a month there and used a guide for the central highlands , as public transport was scarce and 8 years ago. we also used the services of mrs ha for airport transfers and guided tours around hoi an and hue plus her guide in hanoi.
mrs ha vietland discovery tours. i do know that her website was compromised a few years ago so ensure that you do not contact her on a bogus site.
however, you do need to be careful if you are traveling on the lower budget scale, we met many youngsters who had been ripped off by dodgy tour operators.
do check out the weather for september as vietnam has several climate areas including monsoons. we ravelled mid february to mid march where it was sandals and shorts south to north with hanoi being the only place that we need trousers and fleeces.

column5:
if you are travelling with a lot of luggage or are less mobile or suffer from jet lag (or just going on the trip of a lifetime, money no object) a private transfer is likely ‘best’ and frankly there’s not too much in it. heathrow is technically better connected to the fastest route, but if the road is bad gatwick has more options. 9 times out of 10 heathrow will be the better bet, but if you aren’t pushed for time and the fare is dramatically cheaper gatwick is tempting.

column5:
day 9:
we woke up early at around 4:15 am and arindham drove us to the kaziranga national park. he went into the park office and at around 5:10 am, a guy called out our name. it was already bright and there were a lot of tourists. we followed that guy into the park after paying rs 100 camera fees. we went for an elephant safari (rs. 1250 pp). we had to board the elephant from the ramp. the first minute was nervous as the elephant was moving but then we got used to the movement. we spotted rhinos, wild boars, elephants and deer like the previous day. we were able to go very close to a rhino. the ride ended in and hour. arindham drove us back to our hotel and we were served omlette as breakfast.
we went to sleep, woke up at 9:30 and freshend up and left for the airport at 10:30 am. arindham called up someone to prepare for us traditional assamese bamboo lunch. we reached that place at 11:45 am. they made traditional assamese food on skewers and the rice was made in bamboos. the bamboo rice had a flavour of bamboo in it. the food was not really tasty but was very instagrammable. lots of chutneys were served to us while we were seated in bamboo sheds.
at around 12:30, we set off for the airport. the roads gave way to an express highway where we were able to drive at 80 kpmh consistently. the traffic started increasing steadily as we got closer to guwahati and so did the indiscipline of other drivers. we stopped at a place to have curd. the sour and sweet curd were simply delicious.
at around 5:30 pm, we bid goodbye to arindham and went into the airport. we had to get our check-in bags scanned ourselves, but the departure section seemed decent unlike the arrival section. there was even a drinking water station both before and after security. we were hardly 30 passengers in our flight so we boarded and took off around 15 mins before time.

column5:
>> any recommendations to areas to stay kerala sound nice? <<
kerala has several places well worth staying - depending on how long you are staying you might choose a couple.
northern kerala has a string of coastal villages and some lovely beaches which are less visited that those in southern kerala. kannur might be a good option for you.
in central kerala: fort cochin - first and foremost - is a calm spot with plenty of visitor attractions at hand. there are also beaches in this part of the state - cherai and marari for example.
southern kerala: a couple of beach destinations - one at kovalam the other at varkala. also, the joy of kerala is a couple of nights on a houseboat from alleppey.
the western ghats - a mountain range - offer the alternative to coastal life - this region has plenty of national parks, wildlife sanctuaries, trekking and spice, coffee and tea plantations.

column5:
recent trip experience
flew lhr to dxb 14th
emirates check in did not ask reason for travel. quite a few families checking in, either holiday or returning residents. after security, there is a line of border police/regular police spot checking random travellers. they did not pull me over, but i saw some families being questioned. not sure if fpn were being issued.
flight about 1/3 to half full. clearly a lot of people going on holiday but lots of space to distance out.
on arrival, we were thrown into general queues with flights from other destinations to show proof of pcr test. the guy checked mine for a few seconds. on arrival there is also a person holding a board for those to get tested on arrival and they are then taken away, but remarkably allowed to join up with everyone at the baggage carousel a few minutes later with no one accompanying them.
airport was packed.even at 4.40 am. zero distancing in queues and all flights mixed in together going through border control. relatively quick process to get though (less than half an hour). immigration also ask for pcr test so it is checked twice.
hotel asked for nothing re pcr test on arrival. guests not bothering with social distancing or masks around the pool or lobby so giving it a wide berth! hope that helps

column5:
good morning panchopup
actually, as we so often get questions from people who just want to go to bath, bourton on the water and the isle of skye, it’s quite refreshing to see one which combines the otherwise oddly disparate destinations you’ve raised.
have you considered buying open jaw air tickets, maybe arriving in scotland and leaving from london? if you did this you could construct a zigzag trip going glasgow, aberystwyth, norwich, heathrow, which, according to a bing map search would, direct, be 729 miles in total. in british terms this is a lot of driving but in three weeks, and as it for a specific purpose rather than random sightseeing, it would be entirely possible. as all of these places have railway stations, you could do the trip by train, with several changes on the way, but a car would give you flexibility and you could take in some interesting sights en route without lengthening your driving overmuch. for instance, close to the direct route from glasgow to aberystwyth there are two wonderful national parks (the lake district and snowdonia) and you could stop over for two or three nights in either or both of these. there’s also the fine city of liverpool of course, and, for a contrast, the roman/medieval cathedral city of chester. standard advice here is not to do lots of one-night-stands but to pace your journey and get to know fewer places well rather than more places superficially.
aberystwyth to norwich is far from being a ‘standard’ tourist trip but you could explore the welsh borders en route – consider the fine old town of ludlow as a stopover. lichfield is a delightful cathedral city, off the well-trodden tourist track, and cambridge wouldn’t be a very big detour. norwich itself is a great small city and one which tends to be unjustly missed by overseas visitors purely because of its geography.
all this is obviously exceptionally covid-dependent and i think you realise that the chances of it being possible safely and legally this season are less than evens. bear in mind too that late july and august are high season touristically and i suspect more british people will tend to be holidaying, if at all, within britain rather than overseas. finally, a website called university rooms offers accommodation actually within university colleges and halls of residence outside term time. worth a look if you haven’t already, although for obvious reasons they won’t be taking bookings just now.

we usually stay in the beautiful kingdom of fife for a week every year as we prefer to have a base rather than trekking around packing and unpacking, and find fife ideal as there is so much to see and do.
we have stayed in both coastal (crail, pittenweem and burntisland) and inland areas near glenrothes and cupar) and have enjoyed staying in them all!
as you have said you want coastal areas i'd look for accommodation anywhere from aberdour, burntisland, lower largo, lundin links, elie, st monans, pittenweem, anstruther, cellardyke, crail, kingsbarns and st andrews. i know it's a long list but all of these places are lovely.
to narrow it down look for what's available in your budget and what is important to you, eg whether there is free parking available nearby and what there is to walk to from the accommodation regarding shops, places to eat etc.
i would also consider stopping over in northumberland which is another beautiful county with much to offer if you can as you'll find it a long drive from cambridgeshire to fife in one go.
i'm sure you will have an excellent time on the stunning east coast.

column5:
my father and i spent 3 weeks in the north in sept 2019, as follows:
- the first two days and last two days in hanoi
- 4 days in bac ha (night train to lao cai, then 2hr bus trip to bac ha)
- 2 days with a car and driver, driving from bac ha to ha giang, staying overnight in hoang su phi
- 10 days riding a motorbike from ha giang to cao bang, via dong van, meo vac, bao lac etc.
- cao bang to hanoi by luxury mini-van (very comfortable 6hr trip)
i have been to bac ha several times and it is one of my favourite places in the country. there are practically no tourists throughout the week, except for a few which come for the large, excellent sunday market. there are many ethnic groups in the surrounding mountains and it is a great area for trekking, or exploring by motor scooter, or with a car and driver.
i mention bac ha as it makes a good starting point. it is easy to arrange a car and driver there to drive to ha giang via hoang su phi. it would then make a lot of sense to continue on with the same driver to dong van, meo vac, bao lac and perhaps as far as cao bang.
it is sensible to leave hanoi by night train on either wed or thurs night, so you then arrive in bac ha on thurs or fri morning. you can easily go to the nearby can cau market on sat morning and the big sunday market in bac ha town itself.

column5:
hi julie: i've been an indonesian resident since the suharto era so my perspective will be different from some others. this is a topic of frequent discussion amongst indonesians as well as expats or tourists who have been here for a while. indonesia is actually quite a wealthy country and while the government has not been hugely supportive, they do have active programs for healthcare and other supports that go to the villages which distribute aid. there are also probably hundreds of local groups that are doing support activities such as food distribution. also, many of the people who were working in the tourism industry were actually from other islands and those are the people who don't have as much family or banjar support, they have started to go back to their hometowns, at least many of the ones i know. many of the people i know who worked as drivers are now farming, opening small businesses, but paying car loans are the part that worries me. you would be surprised at how much economic activity is going on here, building for instance is booming (yes even large hotels stil being built, villas and buildings are refurbishing, the eateries that catered mostly to foreign tourists are suffering the most, but local cafes are surprisingly still doing ok. many hotels have staff on 2 or 3 days a week rather than 5 or 6, for reduced wages, even if they don't have many rooms occupied they still have to do proper maintenance. you may not know this, but legally companies that lay people off have to pay very large severance packages based on length of service, wages, etc so many are living off that..(and i know people who have gotten several hundred million rupiah as severance)
many "investors" have started to vulture scopping up land and real estate deals..and the balinese i know stil have the resources to hold the line to avoid selling out for extremely low prices.
in the media bali and to a larger extent all of indonesia is often pictured as a poor country with poor resources and begging from help from the outside , a media frenzy if you will, of neo-colonialsm. it's not really as many think...yes we buy or filter our drinking water, but then so do many in my own "first world" country. public transport was given a few tries but very few people used it (due to many factors). i could go on and on but don't have the time right now...as i say these kinds of conversations abound within indonesia and i woudl have to write a book to touch on everything!

column5:
you mentioned hearing 'bad things' about bali and you're right to be skeptical. i've heard the same about turkey, the us, sydney (from country folk) etc etc and i place the blame at the media's feet. the aussie media in particular love a good bali bad news story and don't miss an opportunity to slag the place off, usually from the comfort of their offices in australia.
not to say that bali is perfectly safe and without risk - things can and do happen, and you have to be as sensible as you would be anywhere else. the main things to watch out for are petty theft, cash machine scams, motorcycle accidents (if you're inexperienced) and dodgy food practices - violent crime seems to be relatively rare. obviously not the ingredients for a juicy news story, but that's often the way with the truth.
you won't have any problem getting away from the young party crowd - others have pointed out great areas to visit that would suit you. a lot of it is touristy but not in a bad way - the range and quality of food and shops is usually great to cater for the tourists.
yes, it's changed over the years, and it is sad to see less of the local stuff and more of the global shops but the balinese culture permeates everything, even in downtown kuta, with incense and offerings outside the shops and temples interspersed throughout.
it's a place that has something to suit everyone's taste, from uber luxury to backpackers and everyone in between - the vast majority of people who visit love it and many come back again and again (and in the case of the members of this forum, again and again and again. well we would if we could).
if you have the chance, go.
